contentrichtext.text: {{Redirect|Kablooey|the 2008 film|Kabluey}} {{Infobox VG | title=Bombuzal | image = [[File:Bombuzal c64 box art.jpg|252px|Bombuzal]] |caption = [[Commodore 64]] cover art | developer=[[Image Works]] | publisher=Image Works [[Kemco]] | designer=[[Antony Crowther]], David Bishop | genre=[[Puzzle video game|Puzzle]] | released=1988 | modes=[[Single-player video game|Single player]] | platforms=[[Amiga]], [[Atari ST]], [[Commodore 64]], [[MS-DOS]], [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]] | input=[[Keyboard (computing)|Keyboard]], [[Joystick]] }} '''''Bombuzal''''' is a [[Puzzle video game|computer puzzle game]] designed by [[Antony Crowther]] (credited as ''Ratt'' in the game) and David Bishop for [[Image Works]].<ref>[http://hol.abime.net/180 Bombuzal] on Hall of the Amiga site</ref> The game was released in 1988 for the [[Amiga]], [[Atari ST]] and [[Commodore 64]]. It was also released in 1989 for [[MS-DOS]] and 1990 for the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]], with the North American version renamed as ''Ka-Blooey''. The game had sequel/remake available only for the [[Nintendo 64]] called ''[[Charlie Blast's Territory]]''. Among its notable features was the ability to play using either an overhead or [[isometric projection|isometric]] view. ==Gameplay== To complete each of its 130 levels, the avatar has to destroy all bombs on the level. He must stand on top of the bomb to light it, then is only able to take one step away before the bomb explodes; he can also pick up and move bombs, but only the ones that are on Rail tiles. Bombs come in different sizes and it is only possible to ignite the smallest kind without dying. In most cases, the bombs have to be set off using a [[chain reaction]] to prevent the avatar from being killed in the explosion; at other times, separated small bombs can be destroyed one at a time. Each Bomb/Mine has a reaction zone. For example, a small bomb will only destroy the tile it's on, but will affect any other Bombs/Mines one tile away in the four main directions. A Large bomb will destroy 13 tiles, and its reaction zone will be one tile farther away than the tiles destroyed in each of the four directions, and diagonally between these four points.<ref>Super Nintendo Instruction Booklet page 21.</ref> The game featured level designs by several gaming celebrities, including [[Jon Ritman]], [[Andrew Braybrook]], [[Geoff Crammond]] and [[Jeff Minter]]. Jeff Minter's level blew up to leave behind a llama dropping a pile of dung. The Amiga version of ''Bombuzal'' was included as a fully working game on the [[Covermount|cover disk]] of the first issue of ''[[Amiga Power]]''. There are also two enemies, Sinister and Dexter, appearing on some levels. These continuously travel along the level, with Sinister always turning left and Dexter always turning right. Neither Sinister nor Dexter actively pursues the avatar, but contact with either is fatal. ==Reception== The game received mixed reviews. It received 97% and 92% ratings from [[Zzap!64]]<ref>{{Citation|title=Bombuzal review|publisher=[[Zzap!64|Zzap]]|issue=44|pages=18–19|author=Maff Evans, Paul Glancey, Kati Hamza|date=December 1988}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Bombuzal review|publisher=[[Zzap!64|Zzap]]|issue=45|pages=103|author=Gordon Houghton, Kati Hamza|date=January 1989}}</ref> magazine for the C64 and Amiga versions respectively, compared to a review in [[Commodore User]]<ref>{{Citation|title=Bombuzal review|publisher=[[Commodore User]]|pages=26–27|author=Tony Dillon|date=November 1988}}</ref> magazine awarding a mere 49%. The former reviews applaud it as an addictive puzzle game with "cute" graphics, while the latter criticizes gameplay, graphics, and controls. The game was released by Spotlight Software and distributed by [[Cinemaware]] in the compilation ''BrainBlasters'' with ''[[Super Xevious|Xevious 2]]'' for the [[Amiga]]. This compilation was reviewed in 1991 in ''[[Dragon (magazine)|Dragon]]'' #165 by Hartley, Patricia, and Kirk Lesser in "The Role of Computers" column. The reviewers gave ''BrainBlasters'' 5 out of 5 stars.<ref name="Dragon165">{{Citation |title=The Role of Computers |author=Lesser, Hartley, Patricia, and Kirk |journal=Dragon |issue=165 |date=January 1991 |pages=47–55 |postscript=.}}</ref> ==References== <references/> ==External links== *[http://hol.abime.net/180 ''Bombuzal''] on the Amiga at [http://hol.abime.net/ The Hall of Light (HOL)] *{{moby game|id=/bombuzal|name=''Bombuzal''}} *[http://www.lemon64.com/games/details.php?ID=337 ''Bombuzal''] at Lemon64 *[http://www.m3dr.com/projects/bombzuka/index.html Remake in 3D for PC] [[Category:1988 video games]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:Amiga games]] [[Category:Atari ST games]] [[Category:Commodore 64 games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:Cancelled ZX Spectrum games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]]
